reviewText: I'm a thirtysomething Black male from the inner city in a Southern town. Every time I stumble upon a film like this, I'm excited. But then, I'm saddened that films like this rarely make it into the hands of people like me. Beyond socio-economic demographics, our young people today are force fed some quite non-quality materials, and it's passed off as the trend of a generation. Well, it'll be a generation lost.Okay, off my soapbox. I loved the cinematography of this film. There was a subtle richness that often made you feel like you were really in a tropical locale. Acting doesn't get any better than when the high ranking officer has to get a surgical procedure and.....well, I don't want to spoil it but hi-jinx ensue! I've spent years (pre- and post- Google) trying to find the name of this film until I remember Jack Nicholson had a bit role in it. This is one I hope to be able to enjoy with my three sons: that's if I can pull them away from such timeless classics as SpongeBob or Ben-10.
summary: A classic that today's youth probably will never see

reviewText: Ensign Pulver, played by Robert Walker, is the trailer to "Mister Roberts". In this zany follow up Pulver, plots to maintain the moral of his fellow shipmates during WWII, as a Navy officer stuck on a supply boat, Captained by Burl Ives, the relentless, obessive Captain, who wants to get his next promotion no matter what his crew has to endure. Pulver, the ship's laundry officer stays out of the Captains way, as he plans his revengeful encounters on the Captain.. Fate has a hand in things later in the movie, as Pulver and the Captain are lost at sea and stranded on an island. Watch the antics of Pulver as he becomes the hero in this light hearted movie. He wins the respect of his fellow shipmates and allows the Captain to get his promotion.Ensign Pulver Aug.-Oct. 1964WWII movies made to make us laugh!

reviewText: So thankful that this DVD FINALLY became available.  Ever since I watched 'Mr. Roberts' in my teens I have searched for this movie once I knew it had been filmed.  Now I feel the story is finally complete.  Sure, it is comical but after touring a WWII Battleship I realzied even more the importance of humor on a large ship.  It is not like you could leave the house and go to a movie everyday.

reviewText: This is not a bad sequel from director Joshua Logan. It more or less picks up where MISTER ROBERTS left off but is presented with an entirely knew cast in familiar roles. Robert Walker Jr. is Ensign Pulver. Burl Ives is the Captain. Walter Matthau is good as Doc. He has the cynicism and wit but lacks the good-natured purpose of being that William Powell demonstrated in MISTER ROBERTS. To its credit the film tries to uncover the facade that the Captain wears night and day. Is he really a no good miserable excuse for a human being or is there something lurking deep inside that keeps his humanity from emerging. Pulver sets out unravel the enigma. There are some great moments of comedy and humanity and the film does have a great supporting cast that includes Jack Nicholson, James Farentino, Millie Perkins, Tommy Sands, Al Freeman, Jr., James Coco and Larry Hagman that keeps it all moving.
Title: N/A

reviewText: This movie is a sequel to "Mr. Roberts", a really good movie. It is tough to make a sequel as good as the original, especially with an entirely new cast,This one does a pretty fair job of it. Robert Walker takes over for Jack Lemmon as Ensign Pulver, and does it quite well. Walter Matthau plays the doctor, and Burl Ives is the Captain. there are some other familiar faces that pop up as well.It is light fun and an enjoyable movie.
summary: sequel to a really good movie

reviewText: Interesting how the passage of decades can change one's perspective.When I first screened this I remember feeling sick. In my mind it was black and white with no compromise - there could be no replacement for Jack Lemmon & Co. And unless he was going to reprise his role - then no one could or should. Remember, he won an Academy Award for his performance as Ensign Pulver - it was that good. Anything and anyone that came after was never going to be enough.Saw this film again for the first time in more than a quarter century.I was wrong.Today, it's my belief that one should see this as a complete and standalone production with no connection to 'Mister Roberts' the film. It is in fact proximally closer to 'Mister Roberts' the stage play.What changed my mind were the truly outstanding performances of co-stars Robert Walker Jr. and Burl Ives.Walker's energetic and amusing take on said ensign was genuine; an approach that I felt was touching and very real. While Ives is a true chameleon! A powerhouse performance that can honestly be described as incredible. While not taking anything away from the amazing Jimmy Cagney, whose interpretation of the character was petty and conniving, but generally "all there" - Burl sent the character to the edge of sanity. A startling execution as the driven, maniacal and severely damaged Captain Morton which, in my mind, completely redefined the role. Hard to believe this is the the same person who was the saintly songster and cuddly Christmas character of my youth.The one character whom I thought had lost a step in the sequel was 'Doc'. Terribly missed was the immortal William Powell and his subtle interpretation as the wise elder; the insightful physician whose gentle prods and careful manipulations were a much better fit than Walther Matthau's scream-infused gesticulated interpretation of the same man.We pick up the story several months since the tragic news that Mr. Roberts was killed after finally escaping 'The Bucket'. That terrible shock being the impetus for mousey Pulver to step up and become the man his friend always hoped was in there. But like all such life altering moments - if it wasn't there before, it won't be there later. Meaning that change, real change, is more than just an involuntary reflex to a bad situation. It takes a profound effort to become a different person.Too many people today, young and old, pay lip service to such; preferring platitudes and self-righteous aggrandizement instead of an honest look in the mirror. And just like those self-deceiving gasbags of today - Ensign Frank Pulver has regressed backwards.Suddenly, an unexpected sea storm and the understandable ravings of a sailor on the brink of madness coalesce into another moment for Frank to rediscover his manhood for good.But will he recognize it? And will he take a hold and seize the opportunity, not just for himself, but for every beaten and demoralized sailor on The Bucket?Walker's performance was enjoyable, dotted with startling light touches of character brilliance shining through. My unfortunate initial reaction all those years ago was so knee-jerk. And, sadly, shared by critics and audiences alike in 1964.The movie tanked and Robert was excoriated. His movie career never recovered.A terrible injustice. And it's one that his stepfather, legendary producer David O. Selznick, should have foreseen.Very unfortunate. Very unfair.It's my hope that this review will provide another cinephile a different perspective - and perhaps they will give this film another chance.
summary: A Chance To Mend An Injustice

reviewText: This movie is sort like "Mr. Roberts", but funnier.  Burl Ives is the crotchety old Captain of a Navy vessel, and seems to piss off most of his crew with his "set in his ways/follow the rules" methods.  Robert Walker is his antagonist.  Ensign Pulver gets the upper hand by using pranks and trickery, and heroism--thus earning the admiration of his crewmates.  Walter Matthau is another antagonist who seemed to, in his own way as ship's doctor, "win the day for the crew".  It is a funny movie that moves pretty quickly.  Robert Walker is one of those actors that just seems to have two looks in his eyes--mischievous or evil.
summary: Was a little expensive, but worth it...

reviewText: How to make a sequel of Mr. Roberts ? WB and Josh Logan decided to "continue" the s story with a cast of future stars. Here's a partial list of the stars of this movie: Walter Matthau, James Coco, Jack Nicholson, James Farentino,  Larry Hagman , Peter Marshall , Millie Perkins  and Kay Medford. Robert Walker Jr plays Ensign Pulver, the part originated by Jack Lemmon. Walker is not Jack Lemmon but he is agreeable and  understated. Josh Logan wrote the screenplay, and produced and directed the film. The movie has its moments and is a good way to spend a couple of hours.
Title: N/A

reviewText: Although not as classic as Mister Roberts, this is still a great movie. Hech, I didn't even know there was a sequel, so I bought both copies. They have both earned a Top Shelf placing in my bookcase. All characters play great parts, even though James Cagney and Henry Fonda aren't in this movie. It would have been great to see some of the actors from the Mister Roberts, even though the 'new' doc, played by Walter Matthea does a great job. Both he and the "old Ensign" make great movies together! As most movies drag the chain nowadays going for 2-3+ hours, this is one movie I thought could go on and not get boring. Another classic and great fun for all family to enjoy. We wish more movies were like this nowadays. No Swearing, No Violence, No War .... not even a bullet is fired. An allround great movie.

reviewText: I love this movie, I always have. It's the sequel to Mr Roberts and I can remember watching it with my grandmother when she was babysitting us at least 45 years ago. Don't ask me why that memory is so strong but I can remember her getting so tickled when Pulver talks about shooting the captain in the "beautocks" instead of buttocks. Grandma is long gone but I will always have her in my heart and this movie just brings that memory closer.That being said, most sequels are really terrible, but this one works to the tune of three stars (the fourth is for the previous memory). Even if it didn't the fact that Millie Perkins is in it would make it worth watching. Burl Ives and Walter Matthau chew the scenery and it's really fun to see some people that went on to be quite famous later in life performing in early bit parts including Peter Marshall, Larry Hagman and Jack Nicholson.

reviewText: This movie, although no where near the classic status of Mr. Roberts, from which it is drawn, is a decent comedy.Robert Walker takes over the role of Jack Lemmon and Burl Ives, not James Cagney, is the captain. Walter  Matthau is great as the ship's doctor. It has some great comedic moments  ("tastes like dead frogs.")Again, not a classic, but worth  viewing.
summary: One must divorce all thoughts of Mr. Roberts to truly enjoy.
